A better example of Civil War fiction is the recent movie "Lincoln".

It is almost surely untrue that Thaddeus Stevens was motivated to support African-American suffrage because he had a romantic relationship with a Black lady. The chances that there even was such a relationship are vanishingly small.

His aim for the post-war reconstructed South was to deny any man who served in the Confederate military the right to vote and instead use African-American suffrage as a means of insuring southern states as a solid Republican voting block for at least the next generation, if not the rest of the 19th century.

The movie fails to explain that he owned one of the nation's largest iron production companies and promptly moved to impose a 47% tariff on imports shortly after the War began. His company profited immensely from the War and the massive tariff allowed him to inflate prices egregiously.

I would not be surprised if even the most prejudiced - and presumably prominent - anti-southern historians that dominate the Sesquicentennial era are dismayed at the extreme misrepresentations that the movie "Lincoln" is hereafter likely to lead the public to falsely accept as fact.

The government is not going to ration medical care.  What it will do is decide not to spend public money on a test, drug, or procedure that doesn't provide more in expected benefits than it costs.  If you, the almighty (yet all too frequently low-information) consumer, want to spend YOUR money on low efficacy medical care, then "please proceed".

The issue that needs to be addressed when discussing welfare is not if conservatives are making a case for more welfare but rather what is the most responsible way to deliver benefits to the recipients. It is irresponsible to remove the recipient from the decision process whether by insurance company policy or by a government rationing board. It distorts markets and promotes rational behavior. Distortion leads to imbalances in supply and demand, lack of innovation, more suffering for the poor, and eventually bankruptcy of the system.

It's not just truckers who are under pressure, thus resulting in drowsy driving. We live in a culture where the employer's interest always rules. How many of us are driving drowsy because of an employer's unreasonable demands on our time? I recall a time when I saw a buck standing in the road in front of my car, which was traveling at about 60 miles an hour down a two-lane country road. At the absolute last second, my brain said "Agh!! Deer!!!!", I slammed on the brakes, and the deer swerved. Why was my reaction time so slow? I'd just left work after yet another twelve hour day - just one in an unbroken line of twelve-hour days in that five-month period during which I had not a single day off.

Add in the other pressures of daily life, which for many include racing from part-time job to part-time job just to make ends meet, and you get a toxic mix of tiredness and the need to make a living.

I used that example because it is readily known and one where the driving is done for a living. The same can be said for any profession that employs drivers and that includes fire departments, ambulance drivers, policemen, taxi drivers - all of whom often work longer shifts.

For the rest of us, being overworked is a real concern. I don't disagree. But what of those above who, like you, haven't had a day off and work too much?

In cases where it is a trucker who fell asleep at the wheel, what should always be investigated are the working conditions at the trucking company, first, before only punishing the driver, further reducing his or her ability to earn a living wage.

It is well-known the tremendous amount of pressure truckers are under to deliver their payloads as quickly as possible. Companies that force drivers to cut corners and drive longer hours than is safe should be penalized.

The question of government encroachment is tertiary to public safety in this and many cases. We have government in place to do things for public good. Government isn't some alien force. We put it there for many reasons.

The first example that comes to mind is trucking. Highway fatalities have declined after years of lax or non-existent supervision of trucking companies' maintenance practices. Who among us doesn't remember all of the reports of faulty brakes causing an accident? Government can be credited for the fact that such reports and the fatalities are no longer the stuff of daily news items.

In the end, regulations that will resolve the falling asleep at the wheel problem benefit all of us, from other drivers to trucking and other companies that employ drivers as their main way of conducting business.

As a physician, I see nurses making poor food choices all the time. The majority that I know are either overweight or obese. They work in environments (hospitals and clinics) that are repositories of unhealthful food, especially soda. Yes, there is soda in hospitals and clinics! Potlucks, drug lunches and incessant snacking. That's what I see. Nurses heal thy selves and so you'll be better able to serve as an example for your patients.

Yes Charles, that is my point. Bad food choices appear in all walks of life.
Some self-restraint is needed as well. We are a nation of over-consumers.

This debate has been going on for a very long time. As a nurse we see bad food choices in all walks of life. Education about nutrition is lacking for many; even the well heeled. And good luck finding decent produce in poor urban areas. Many times there are no grocery stores and shopping is done at the local mini mart.

I have also met people eligible for SNAP but have declined because they were ashamed. We need to get rid of the shame factor. They are all not buying sodas and ding dongs. It isn't easy for a lot of these parents. They are just trying to get by.

I don't have an answer to throw at you, Maureen. The number of times I should have been killed in Vietnam but wasn't, yet others, friends, were; I got up the next morning, put on the company radio to carry for the CO, picked up my rifle and moved on. 14 months and home, not a scratch on my body despite the NVA's best efforts to destroy this radio man on many occasions.

But not my buddies. 14 of them in 14 months and 65 wounded.

Why? Because. That's why. Fair has nothing to do with it.

In the end I come back to "Nature Boy," that strange haunting song from decades ago:

There was a boy, a very strange enchanted boy,
they say he wandered very far
very far
over land and sea
a little shy
and sad of eye
but very wise was he.

And then one day
one magic day he passed my way
and as we spoke of many things,
fools and kings
this he said to me
"The greatest thing
you'll every learn
is just to love
and be loved in return."

I love the guys I served with and always will. We weren't necessarily good people, But on a given day you could rely on every man to save you or to be saved. Then, and now, "I say a few words to the close and holy darkness," as Dylan Thomas observed, and I sleep.

Hope is all we have. Maybe it's God.
